custom_item_316.description: AIX7-00-002083 - The AIX /etc/group file must be owned by root.
custom_item_316.info: The '/etc/group' file contains information regarding groups that are configured on the system. Protection of this file is important for system security.
custom_item_316.solution:
Change the owner of the '/etc/group' file to 'root':
# chown root /etc/group

custom_item_317.description: AIX7-00-002084 - The AIX /etc/group file must be group-owned by security.
custom_item_317.info: The '/etc/group' file contains information regarding groups that are configured on the system. Protection of this file is important for system security.
custom_item_317.solution:
Change the group of the '/etc/group' file to 'security':
# chgrp security /etc/group

custom_item_318.description: AIX7-00-002091 - The AIX /etc/group file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_318.info: The '/etc/group' file contains information regarding groups that are configured on the system. Protection of this file is important for system security.
custom_item_318.solution:
Change the mode of the '/etc/group' file to '0644':
# chmod 0644 /etc/group

custom_item_319.description: AIX7-00-002092 - The inetd.conf file on AIX must be group owned by the 'system' group - system group.
custom_item_319.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to system groups may provide unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_319.solution:
Change the group ownership of '/etc/inetd.conf':
# chgrp system /etc/inetd.conf

custom_item_320.description: AIX7-00-002093 - The AIX /etc/inetd.conf file must have a mode of 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_320.info: Failure to set proper permissions of sensitive files or utilities may provide unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_320.solution:
Change the ownership of the file to root using command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/inetd.conf

custom_item_321.description: AIX7-00-003015 - The AIX /etc/group file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_321.info: The '/etc/group' file contains information regarding groups that are configured on the system. Protection of this file is important for system security.
custom_item_321.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the '/etc/group' using command:
# acledit /etc/group

custom_item_322.description: AIX7-00-003016 - The AIX ldd command must be disabled.
custom_item_322.info: The ldd command provides a list of dependent libraries needed by a given binary, which is useful for troubleshooting software. Instead of parsing the binary file, some ldd implementations invoke the program with a special environment variable set, which causes the system dynamic linker to display the list of libraries. Specially crafted binaries can specify an alternate dynamic linker which may cause a program to be executed instead of examined. If the program is from an untrusted source, such as in a user home directory, or a file suspected of involvement in a system compromise, unauthorized software may be executed with the rights of the user running ldd.
custom_item_322.solution:
Disable the 'ldd' command by removing its permissions using command:
# chmod 0000

custom_item_323.description: AIX7-00-001035 - The Group Identifiers (GIDs) reserved for AIX system accounts must not be assigned to non-system accounts as their primary group GID.
custom_item_323.info: Reserved GIDs are typically used by system software packages. If non-system groups have GIDs in this range, they may conflict with system software, possibly leading to the group having permissions to modify system files.
custom_item_323.solution:
Change the primary GID for non-system accounts that have reserved GIDs as their primary GIDs using the following command:
# chuser pgrp=

custom_item_329.description: AIX7-00-003038 - AIX sendmail logging must not be set to less than nine in the sendmail.cf file.
custom_item_329.info: If Sendmail is not configured to log at level 9, system logs may not contain the information necessary for tracking unauthorized use of the sendmail service.
custom_item_329.solution:
Edit /etc/mail/sendmail.cf file, locate the 'O LogLevel' line, or add a new line if necessary, and change the log level to '9'. The new LogLevel line should be:
O LogLevel=9

custom_item_330.description: AIX7-00-003039 - AIX run control scripts executable search paths must contain only absolute paths.
custom_item_330.info:
The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_330.solution: Edit the run control script and remove the relative path entry from the executable search path variable.

custom_item_333.description: AIX7-00-003017 - AIX NFS server must be configured to restrict file system access to local hosts.
custom_item_333.info: The NFS access option limits user access to the specified level. This assists in protecting exported file systems. If access is not restricted, unauthorized hosts may be able to access the system's NFS exports.
custom_item_333.solution:
Edit '/etc/exports' and add 'ro' and/or 'rw' options (as appropriate) specifying a list of hosts or networks which are permitted access.

Re-export the file systems:
# /usr/sbin/exportfs -a

custom_item_334.description: AIX7-00-003112 - AIX must be configured to only boot from the system boot device - bootlist
custom_item_334.info: The ability to boot from removable media is the same as being able to boot into single user or maintenance mode without a password. This ability could allow a malicious user to boot the system and perform changes possibly compromising or damaging the system. It could also allow the system to be used for malicious purposes by a malicious anonymous user.
custom_item_334.solution:
Configure the system to only boot from system startup media:
# bootlist -m normal hdiskSet 'multi-boot' to 'off' in the SMS application.

custom_item_339.description: AIX7-00-002057 - AIX audit logs must be rotated daily.
custom_item_339.info:
Rotate audit logs daily to preserve audit file system space and to conform to the DoD/DISA requirement. If it is not rotated daily and moved to another location, then there is more of a chance for the compromise of audit data by malicious users.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_339.solution: Configure a cron job or other automated process to rotate the audit logs on a daily basis.

custom_item_341.description: AIX7-00-003114 - If the AIX host is running an SMTP service, the SMTP greeting must not provide version information.
custom_item_341.info: The version of the SMTP service can be used by attackers to plan an attack based on vulnerabilities present in the specific version.
custom_item_341.solution:
Ensure 'Sendmail' or its equivalent has been configured to mask the version information. If necessary, change the 'O SmtpGreetingMessage' line in the '/etc/sendmail.cf' file from:
O SmtpGreetingMessage=$j Sendmail $v/$Z; $b

to:

O SmtpGreetingMessage= Mail Server Ready ; $b

custom_item_342.description: AIX7-00-003115 - AIX must contain no .forward files.
custom_item_342.info: The .forward file allows users to automatically forward mail to another system. Use of .forward files could allow the unauthorized forwarding of mail and could potentially create mail loops which could degrade system performance.
custom_item_342.solution:
Run the following command to remove all '.forward' files on the system:
# find / -name .forward -exec rm -rf {} \;

custom_item_343.description: AIX7-00-002131 - AIX must implement a remote syslog server that is documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_343.info:
If a remote log host is in use and it has not been justified and documented, sensitive information could be obtained by unauthorized users without the administrator's knowledge.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227, SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224
custom_item_343.solution: Edit the /etc/syslog.conf file to include a documented and approved remote log host.

custom_item_344.description: AIX7-00-002063 - AIX must be configured with a default gateway for IPv4 if the system uses IPv4, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_344.info: If a system has no default gateway defined, the system is at increased risk of man-in-the-middle, monitoring, and Denial of Service attacks.
custom_item_344.solution:
Set a default gateway for IPv4 using:
# route add 0

custom_item_345.description: AIX7-00-003116 - The sendmail server must have the debug feature disabled on AIX systems.
custom_item_345.info: Debug mode is a feature present in older versions of Sendmail which, if not disabled, may allow an attacker to gain access to a system through the Sendmail service.
custom_item_345.solution: Obtain and install a more recent version of 'Sendmail', which does not implement the DEBUG feature.

custom_item_347.description: AIX7-00-003117 - SMTP service must not have the EXPN or VRFY features active on AIX systems.
custom_item_347.info: The SMTP EXPN function allows an attacker to determine if an account exists on a system, providing significant assistance to a brute force attack on user accounts. EXPN may also provide additional information concerning users on the system, such as the full names of account owners. The VRFY (Verify) command allows an attacker to determine if an account exists on a system, providing significant assistance to a brute force attack on user accounts. VRFY may provide additional information about users on the system, such as the full names of account owners.
custom_item_347.solution:
Edit the 'sendmail.cf' file and add or edit the following line:
O PrivacyOptions=goaway

Restart the 'Sendmail' service:
# startsrc -s sendmail -a '-bd -q30m'

custom_item_348.description: AIX7-00-001036 - UIDs reserved for system accounts must not be assigned to non-system accounts on AIX systems.
custom_item_348.info:
Reserved UIDs are typically used by system software packages. If non-system accounts have UIDs in this range, they may conflict with system software, possibly leading to the user having permissions to modify system files.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_348.solution:
Using the 'usermod' command, change the UID numbers for non-system accounts with reserved UIDs (those less or equal to 128):
# usermod -u[user_name]

custom_item_361.description: AIX7-00-003093 - AIX process core dumps must be disabled.
custom_item_361.info: A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems.

custom_item_362.description: AIX7-00-003122 - The SMTP service HELP command must not be enabled on AIX.
custom_item_362.info: The HELP command should be disabled to mask version information. The version of the SMTP service software could be used by attackers to target vulnerabilities present in specific software versions.
custom_item_362.solution:
To disable the SMTP service HELP command remove the HELP file using command:
# rm
custom_item_362.cmd: helpfile=`/usr/bin/grep HelpFile /etc/mail/sendmail.cf| /usr/bin/cut -d'=' -f2`;if [[ -f $helpfile ]]; then echo "Fail - $helpfile found"; else echo "Pass - $helpfile not found"; fi

custom_item_363.description: AIX7-00-002132 - The AIX syslog daemon must not accept remote messages unless it is a syslog server documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_363.info: Unintentionally running a syslog server accepting remote messages puts the system at increased risk. Malicious syslog messages sent to the server could exploit vulnerabilities in the server software itself, could introduce misleading information in to the system's logs, or could fill the system's storage leading to a Denial of Service.
custom_item_363.solution:
Change the 'syslogd' arguments in the src subsystem control and restart the 'syslogd' daemon using the following commands:
# chssys -s syslogd -a '-R'
# stopsrc -s syslogd
# startsrc -s syslogd

custom_item_366.description: AIX7-00-002064 - IP forwarding for IPv4 must not be enabled on AIX unless the system is a router.
custom_item_366.info: IP forwarding permits the kernel to forward packets from one network interface to another. The ability to forward packets between two networks is only appropriate for systems acting as routers.
custom_item_366.solution:
Disable IPv4 forwarding on the system by running command:
# no -p -o ipforwarding=0

custom_item_367.description: AIX7-00-003123 - NIS maps must be protected through hard-to-guess domain names on AIX.
custom_item_367.info:
The use of hard-to-guess NIS domain names provides additional protection from unauthorized access to the NIS directory information.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_367.solution: Change the NIS domain name to a value difficult to guess. Consult vendor documentation for the required procedure.
custom_item_367.cmd: /usr/bin/domainname 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ if (NF == 0) print "no domain name set"; else print }'

custom_item_368.description: AIX7-00-003124 - The AIX systems access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts - /etc/hosts.allow
custom_item_368.info: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.
custom_item_368.solution:
Edit the '/etc/hosts.allow' and '/etc/hosts.deny' files to configure access restrictions.

Add 'ALL: ALL' entry to '/etc/hosts.deny' file.

custom_item_369.description: AIX7-00-001037 - The AIX root accounts list of preloaded libraries must be empty - /etc/hosts.deny
custom_item_369.info: The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary. If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded.
custom_item_369.solution: Edit the 'root' user's initialization files and remove any definition of 'LDR_PRELOAD'.

custom_item_370.description: AIX7-00-003124 - The AIX systems access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts - /etc/hosts.deny ALL:ALL
custom_item_370.info: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.
custom_item_370.solution:
Edit the '/etc/hosts.allow' and '/etc/hosts.deny' files to configure access restrictions.

Add 'ALL: ALL' entry to '/etc/hosts.deny' file.

custom_item_371.description: AIX7-00-003126 - AIX control scripts library search paths must contain only absolute paths.
custom_item_371.info: The library search path environment variable(s) contain a list of directories for the dynamic linker to search to find libraries. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, libraries in these directories may be loaded instead of system libraries. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_371.solution: Edit run control scripts' library search 'PATH' variables. Remove empty entries or entries that are not absolute paths.

custom_item_372.description: AIX7-00-003127 - The control script lists of preloaded libraries must contain only absolute paths on AIX systems.
custom_item_372.info: The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary. If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded.
custom_item_372.solution: Edit the run control scripts' library preload list and remove relative paths.

custom_item_380.description: AIX7-00-003130 - The local initialization file lists of preloaded libraries must contain only absolute paths on AIX.
custom_item_380.info: The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary. If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded. This variable is formatted as a space-separated list of libraries.
custom_item_380.solution: Edit the local initialization file and remove the relative path entry from the library preload variable 'LDR_PRELOAD'.

custom_item_381.description: AIX7-00-001139 - AIX removable media, remote file systems, and any file system not containing approved device files must be mounted with the nodev option.
custom_item_381.info:
The nodev (or equivalent) mount option causes the system to not handle device files as system devices. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved device files. Device files can provide direct access to system hardware and can compromise security if not protected.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_381.solution: Edit '/etc/filesystems' and add the 'options = nodev' to all entries for remote or removable media file systems, and file systems containing no approved device files.

custom_item_382.description: AIX7-00-003094 - AIX kernel core dumps must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_382.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash. Kernel core dumps may consume a considerable amount of disk space and may result in Denial of Service by exhausting the available space on the target file system. The kernel core dump process may increase the amount of time a system is unavailable due to a crash. Kernel core dumps can be useful for kernel debugging.
custom_item_382.solution:
Disable kernel core dumps on the system by setting primary and secondary dump devices to 'sysdumpnull' by running following commands:
# sysdumpdev -P -p /dev/sysdumpnull
# sysdumpdev -P -s /dev/sysdumpnull
custom_item_382.cmd: /usr/bin/sysdumpdev -l | /usr/bin/egrep '(primary|secondary)' | grep -v 'sysdumpnull' | /usr/bin/awk '{print} END {if (NR == 2) print "Primary and secondary configured correctly"}'

custom_item_383.description: AIX7-00-002113 - The AIX SSH daemon must not allow compression.
custom_item_383.info: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection, potentially with root privileges.
custom_item_383.solution:
Edit the '/etc/ssh/sshd_config' file and add (or modify) the following line:
Compression no

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_384.description: AIX7-00-002065 - AIX must be configured with a default gateway for IPv6 if the system uses IPv6 unless the system is a router.
custom_item_384.info: If a system has no default gateway defined, the system is at increased risk of man-in-the-middle, monitoring, and Denial of Service attacks.
custom_item_384.solution:
Configure an IPv6 default route on the system:
# smitty route

custom_item_385.description: AIX7-00-002066 - AIX must not have IP forwarding for IPv6 enabled unless the system is an IPv6 router.
custom_item_385.info: If the system is configured for IP forwarding and is not a designated router, it could be used to bypass network security by providing a path for communication not filtered by network devices.
custom_item_385.solution:
Disable IPv6 forwarding on the system:
# /usr/sbin/no -p -o ip6forwarding=0

custom_item_386.description: AIX7-00-003131 - AIX package management tool must be used daily to verify system software.
custom_item_386.info: Verification using the system package management tool can be used to determine that system software has not been tampered with. This requirement is not applicable to systems not using package management tools.
custom_item_386.solution:
Add a job to the root crontab invoking the following system package management tool to verify the integrity of installed packages and email the result to root user.

Run the following command to add the cron job:
# crontab -e

Within crontab command, add the following daily job to the cron table, then save the change:
0 23 * * * /usr/bin/lppchk -c > /tmp/111 2>&1; sendmail root < /tmp/111

custom_item_389.description: AIX7-00-003133 - AIX must not run any routing protocol daemons unless the system is a router.
custom_item_389.info: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.
custom_item_389.solution:
Kill any routing protocol daemons by running the following command:
# ps -ef |egrep '(ospf|route|bgp|zebra|quagga|gate)' | grep -v egrep | awk -F ' ' '{print $2}' | while read pid;do kill $pid;done

custom_item_393.description: AIX7-00-003135 - AIX must not respond to ICMPv6 echo requests sent to a broadcast address.
custom_item_393.info: Responding to broadcast ICMP echo requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.
custom_item_393.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to IPv6 multicast ICMP ECHO_REQUESTs by running:
# /usr/sbin/no -p -o bcastping=0

custom_item_397.description: AIX7-00-002114 - AIX must turn on SSH daemon privilege separation.
custom_item_397.info: SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section.
custom_item_397.solution:
Edit the '/etc/sshd/sshd_config' file and add the following line:
UsePrivilegeSeparation yes

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_398.description: AIX7-00-002115 - AIX must turn on SSH daemon reverse name checking.
custom_item_398.info: If reverse name checking is off, SSH may allow a remote attacker to circumvent security policies and attempt to or actually login from IP addresses that are not permitted to access resources.
custom_item_398.solution:
Edit the '/etc/sshd/sshd_config' file and add the following line:
VerifyReverseMapping yes

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_399.description: AIX7-00-002116 - AIX SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
custom_item_399.info: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.
custom_item_399.solution:
Edit the '/etc/sshd/sshd_config' file and add or change the 'StrictModes'  setting to 'yes'.

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_400.description: AIX7-00-002117 - AIX must turn off X11 forwarding for the SSH daemon.
custom_item_400.info: X11 forwarding over SSH allows for the secure remote execution of X11-based applications. This feature can increase the attack surface of an SSH connection and should not be enabled unless needed.
custom_item_400.solution:
Edit the '/etc/sshd/sshd_config' file to add the following line and save the change:
X11Forwarding no

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_401.description: AIX7-00-002118 - AIX must turn off TCP forwarding for the SSH daemon.
custom_item_401.info: SSH TCP connection forwarding provides a mechanism to establish TCP connections proxied by the SSH server. This function can provide similar convenience to a Virtual Private Network (VPN) with the similar risk of providing a path to circumvent firewalls and network ACLs.
custom_item_401.solution:
Edit the '/etc/sshd/sshd_config' file to add the following line and save the change:
AllowTcpForwarding no

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_404.description: AIX7-00-001038 - AIX must not have accounts configured with blank or null passwords.
custom_item_404.info: If an account is configured for password authentication but does not have an assigned password, it may be possible to log into the account without authentication. If the root user is configured without a password, the entire system may be compromised. For user accounts not using password authentication, the account must be configured with a password lock value instead of a blank or null value.
custom_item_404.solution:
Configure a password for any interactive account with a blank password by running the following command:
# passwd [user_name]

custom_item_409.description: AIX7-00-003139 - The .rhosts file must not be supported in AIX PAM.
custom_item_409.info: .rhosts files are used to specify a list of hosts permitted remote access to a particular account without authenticating. The use of such a mechanism defeats strong identification and authentication requirements.
custom_item_409.solution: Edit '/etc/pam.conf' and remove the reference(s) to the 'rhosts_auth' module.

custom_item_410.description: AIX7-00-002120 - The AIX SSH daemon must be configured to disable empty passwords.
custom_item_410.info: When password authentication is allowed, PermitEmptyPasswords specifies whether the server allows login to accounts with empty password strings. If an account has an empty password, anyone could log in and run commands with the privileges of that account. Accounts with empty passwords should never be used in operational environments.
custom_item_410.solution:
Edit '/etc/ssh/sshd_config' and add or edit the 'PermitEmptyPasswords ' line as:
PermitEmptyPasswords  no

Save the change and restart ssh daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_411.description: AIX7-00-002121 - The AIX SSH daemon must be configured to disable user .rhosts files.
custom_item_411.info: Trust .rhost file means a compromise on one host can allow an attacker to move trivially to other hosts.
custom_item_411.solution:
Edit '/etc/ssh/sshd_config' and add or update the 'IgnoreRhosts ' line as:
IgnoreRhosts  yes

Save the change and restart ssh daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_412.description: AIX7-00-002122 - The AIX SSH daemon must be configured to not use host-based authentication.
custom_item_412.info: SSH trust relationships mean a compromise on one host can allow an attacker to move trivially to other hosts.
custom_item_412.solution:
Edit '/etc/ssh/sshd_config' and add or update the 'HostbasedAuthentication' line as:
HostbasedAuthentication  no

Save the change and restart ssh daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_413.description: AIX7-00-002123 - The AIX SSH daemon must not allow RhostsRSAAuthentication.
custom_item_413.info: If SSH permits rhosts RSA authentication, a user may be able to log in based on the keys of the host originating the request and not any user-specific authentication.
custom_item_413.solution:
Edit the '/etc/ssh/sshd_config file', add the following line, and save the change:
RhostsRSAAuthentication no

Restart the SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_414.description: AIX7-00-003140 - The AIX root user home directory must not be the root directory (/).
custom_item_414.info: Changing the root home directory to something other than / and assigning it a 0700 protection makes it more difficult for intruders to manipulate the system by reading the files that root places in its default directory. It also gives root the same discretionary access control for root's home directory as for the other plain user home directories.
custom_item_414.solution:
The root home directory should be something other than '/' (such as /root).

Run commands:
# mkdir /root
# chown root /root
# chgrp system /root
# chmod 700 /root

Then, edit the passwd file and change the root home directory to '/root'.

custom_item_415.description: GEN000920 - The root home directory is not '/'

custom_item_416.description: AIX7-00-001039 - The AIX root accounts home directory (other than /) must have mode 0700.
custom_item_416.info: Users' home directories/folders may contain information of a sensitive nature. Non-privileged users should coordinate any sharing of information with an SA through shared resources.
custom_item_416.solution:
Use the following command to change protections for the root home directory:
# chmod 0700 /root.

custom_item_417.description: AIX7-00-001040 - The AIX root accounts home directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_417.info: Excessive permissions on root home directories allow unauthorized access to root user files.
custom_item_417.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the 'root' account's home directory using command:
# acledit ~root

Change extended attributes to disabled.

custom_item_418.description: AIX7-00-003019 - The AIX user home directories must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_418.info: Excessive permissions on home directories allow unauthorized access to user files.
custom_item_418.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the user home directory and disable extended permissions:
# acledit
custom_item_418.cmd: /usr/bin/echo $(for f in /home/* ; do /usr/bin/aclget $f | /usr/bin/sed -n '/extended/,/abled/p' | /usr/bin/egrep -v '(extended permissions|disabled)' ; done | /usr/bin/awk '{print} END {if (NR == 0) print "none"}')

custom_item_419.description: AIX7-00-003143 - AIX must employ a deny-all, allow-by-exception firewall policy for allowing connections to other systems.
custom_item_419.info:
Failure to restrict network connectivity only to authorized systems permits inbound connections from malicious systems. It also permits outbound connections that may facilitate exfiltration of DoD data.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_419.solution:
From the command prompt, run the following commands to create and activate 'ipsec_v4' and 'ipsec_v6' devices:
# mkdev -l ipsec -t 4
# mkdev -l ipsec -t 6

From the command prompt, run the following commands to change the 'all traffic' rules to block all packages:
# chfilt -a D -v 4 -n 0
# chfilt -a D -v 6 -n 0

Assume that the local host has IP address 10.10.10.10 and the remote host has IP address 11.11.11.11, run the following command to generate a user-defined filter rule that allow all IPv4 traffic between these 2 hosts:
# genfilt -w B -v 4 -s 10.10.10.10 -p 0 -P 0 -o any -O any -m 255.255.255.255 -M 255.255.255.255 -i all -g Y -d 11.11.11.11 -c all -a P

From the command prompt, run the following command to activate all the filter rules in the rule database:
# mkfilt -u

custom_item_420.description: AIX7-00-002124 - If AIX SSH daemon is required, the SSH daemon must only listen on the approved listening IP addresses.
custom_item_420.info: The SSH daemon should only listen on the approved listening IP addresses. Otherwise the SSH service could be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_420.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon config file and add/modify the 'ListenAddress' network addresses:
# vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config

Restart SSH daemon:
# stopsrc -s sshd
# startsrc -s sshd

custom_item_446.description: AIX7-00-003204 - The AIX operating system must be configured to use a valid server_ca.pem file.
custom_item_446.info:
To assure accountability and prevent unauthenticated access, privileged and non-privileged users must utilize multifactor authentication to prevent potential misuse and compromise of the system.
Multifactor authentication uses two or more factors to achieve authentication.

Factors include:
1. Something you know (e.g., password/PIN);
2. Something you have (e.g., cryptographic identification device, token); and
3. Something you are (e.g., biometric).

The DoD CAC with DoD-approved PKI is an example of multifactor authentication.
custom_item_446.solution: Configure the system to use a valid 'server_ca.pem' file.

custom_item_458.description: AIX7-00-002140 - The AIX /etc/hosts file must be owned by root.
custom_item_458.info: Unauthorized ownership of the /etc/hosts file can lead to the ability for a malicious actor to redirect traffic to servers of their choice. It is also possible to use the /etc/hosts file to block detection by security software by blocking the traffic to all the download or update servers of well-known security vendors.
custom_item_458.solution:
Change the ownership of the file to root using command:
# chown root /etc/hosts

custom_item_459.description: AIX7-00-002141 - The AIX /etc/hosts file must be group-owned by system.
custom_item_459.info: Unauthorized group ownership of the /etc/hosts file can lead to the ability for a malicious actor to redirect traffic to servers of their choice. It is also possible to use the /etc/hosts file to block detection by security software by blocking the traffic to all the download or update servers of well-known security vendors.
custom_item_459.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file to system using command:
# chgrp system /etc/hosts

custom_item_460.description: AIX7-00-002142 - The AIX /etc/hosts file must have a mode of 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_460.info: Unauthorized permissions of the /etc/hosts file can lead to the ability for a malicious actor to redirect traffic to servers of their choice. It is also possible to use the /etc/hosts file to block detection by security software by blocking the traffic to all the download or update servers of well-known security vendors.
custom_item_460.solution:
Change the mode of the file to 0640 using command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/hosts

custom_item_461.description: AIX7-00-002143 - AIX cron and crontab directories must have a mode of 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_461.info: Incorrect permissions of the cron or crontab directories could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter cron jobs and run automated jobs as privileged users. Failure to set proper permissions of cron or crontab directories provides unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_461.solution:
Change the owner of the 'crontab' directory:
# chmod 640 /var/spool/cron/crontabs

custom_item_462.description: AIX7-00-002144 - The AIX /etc/syslog.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_462.info: Unauthorized ownership of the /etc/syslog.conf file can lead to the ability for a malicious actor to alter or disrupt system logging activities. This can aid the malicious actor in avoiding detection and further their ability to conduct malicious activities on the system.
custom_item_462.solution:
Change the ownership of the file to root using command:
# chown root /etc/syslog.conf

custom_item_463.description: AIX7-00-002145 - The AIX /etc/syslog.conf file must be group-owned by system.
custom_item_463.info: Unauthorized group ownership of the /etc/syslog.conf file can lead to the ability for a malicious actor to alter or disrupt system logging activities. This can aid the malicious actor in avoiding detection and further their ability to conduct malicious activities on the system.
custom_item_463.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file to system using command:
# chgrp system /etc/syslog.conf

custom_item_464.description: AIX7-00-002146 - The AIX /etc/syslog.conf file must have a mode of 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_464.info: Unauthorized permissions of the /etc/syslog.conf file can lead to the ability for a malicious actor to alter or disrupt system logging activities. This can aid the malicious actor in avoiding detection and further their ability to conduct malicious activities on the system.
custom_item_464.solution:
Change the mode of the file to 0640 using command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/syslog.conf

custom_item_465.description: AIX7-00-002147 - The AIX /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_465.info: Unauthorized ownership of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter atjobs and run automated jobs as privileged users. Failure to set proper permissions of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory provides unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_465.solution:
Change the ownership of the 'atjobs' directory to bin using command:
# chown bin /var/spool/cron/atjobs

custom_item_466.description: AIX7-00-002148 - The AIX /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory must be group-owned by cron.
custom_item_466.info: Unauthorized group ownership of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter atjobs and run automated jobs as privileged users. Failure to set proper permissions of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory provides unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_466.solution:
Change the group ownership of the 'atjobs' directory to cron using command:
# chgrp cron /var/spool/cron/atjobs

custom_item_467.description: AIX7-00-002149 - The AIX /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory must have a mode of 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_467.info: Incorrect permissions of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter atjobs and run automated jobs as privileged users. Failure to set proper permissions of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory provides unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_467.solution:
Change the mode of the /var/spool/cron/atjobs directory:
# chmod 640 /var/spool/cron/atjobs

custom_item_468.description: AIX7-00-002150 - The AIX cron and crontab directories must be group-owned by cron.
custom_item_468.info: Incorrect group ownership of the cron or crontab directories could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter cron jobs and run automated jobs as privileged users. Failure to give ownership of cron or crontab directories to root or to bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_468.solution:
Change the group owner of the 'crontab' directory:
# chgrp cron /var/spool/cron/crontabs
